description: Beef Bhuna is a popular Bangladeshi dish made with tender chunks of beef cooked in a spicy tomato-based sauce. Khondoker Amir Uddin is a master chef in Bangladesh known for his skill in preparing traditional dishes like Beef Bhuna.
cooking_method: Heat oil in a pan and add chopped onions, garlic, and ginger.
Cook until the onions are soft and translucent.
Add chili powder, cumin powder, coriander powder, turmeric powder, and salt.
Mix well.
Add diced tomatoes and cook until they are soft and mushy.
Add the beef and cook until it is browned on all sides.
Add water and bring the mixture to a boil.
Reduce the heat and simmer until the beef is tender.
Add garam masala and mix well.
Cook for another 5-10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Serve hot with rice or naan bread.

description: Chingri Malai Curry is a classic Bangladeshi dish that features jumbo prawns cooked in a rich and creamy coconut milk sauce. Nirob is a renowned Bangladeshi chef who is known for his expert use of spices and herbs in his cooking.
cooking_method: Heat the ghee in a large pan over medium heat.
Add the onion and cook until softened, about 5 minutes.
Add the garlic and ginger and cook for another minute.
Add the spices and cook for 1-2 minutes, stirring constantly.
Add the prawns and cook until they turn pink, about 3-4 minutes.
Pour in the coconut milk and bring to a simmer.
Cook for 10-15 minutes, or until the sauce has thickened and the prawns are fully cooked.
Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves and serve hot with rice or naan bread.

description: Chicken Korma is a flavorful Bangladeshi dish that is made with succulent chicken pieces cooked in a creamy yogurt and spice-based sauce. Rahima Begum is a talented Bangladeshi chef who has perfected the art of cooking classic Bangladeshi dishes like Chicken Korma.
cooking_method: Wash the chicken pieces and pat them dry.
In a bowl, mix together the yogurt, ginger paste, garlic paste, cumin powder, coriander powder, garam masala, turmeric powder, red chili powder, and salt to taste.
Marinate the chicken pieces in the yogurt mixture for at least 30 minutes, or overnight for best results.
Heat the ghee in a large pot over medium heat.
Add the sliced almonds and raisins, and fry until the almonds are golden brown and the raisins are plump.
Remove the almonds and raisins from the pot and set aside.
Add the marinated chicken to the pot, and cook until the chicken is browned on all sides.
Add the remaining yogurt marinade to the pot and stir well.
Cover the pot and cook the chicken for 20-25 minutes or until the chicken is fully cooked and the sauce has thickened.
Stir in the cream, and cook for an additional 2-3 minutes.
Garnish with the fried almonds and raisins, and serve hot with rice or naan.

description: Biriyani is a classic Bangladeshi dish made with spiced rice and either chicken, beef, or fish. Tommy Miah is a renowned Bangladeshi chef who has popularized this dish in the UK, where he has been awarded an MBE for his contribution to the culinary industry.
cooking_method: To make biriyani, start by marinating your choice of meat in a mixture of yogurt and spices.
Then, cook the basmati rice separately and set it aside.
In a pan, saut√© sliced onions in ghee or oil until they are caramelized.
Add the marinated meat and cook until it is tender.
In a large pot, layer the cooked rice and the meat mixture, starting and ending with rice.
Cover the pot and cook on low heat until the biriyani is fully cooked and the flavors have melded together.

description: Fuchka is a popular street food in Bangladesh, consisting of small fried balls filled with spiced potato or chickpeas, served with a tamarind or mint chutney. Tahmina Islam is a talented Bangladeshi chef who has taken this humble street food and elevated it to a gourmet level with her own unique twist.
cooking_method: To make the Fuchka dough, mix semolina, all-purpose flour and water to form a smooth dough.
Set aside for 30 minutes.
In the meantime, prepare the filling by mashing boiled potatoes or boiled chickpeas, and adding spices to taste.
Form small balls from the dough and fill with the filling.
Deep fry until golden brown.
Serve hot with tamarind or mint chutney.

description: Kacchi Biriyani is a traditional Bangladeshi dish made with spiced rice and marinated goat meat or beef that is slow-cooked in a sealed pot for hours. Shawkat Osman is a highly skilled Bangladeshi chef who has perfected the art of cooking this complex dish.
cooking_method: To make Kacchi Biriyani, first marinate the meat with yogurt, spices, and papaya paste to tenderize it.
Then, parboil the rice and layer it with the meat in a heavy-bottomed pot.
Seal the pot with dough or aluminum foil and cook on low heat for several hours until the meat is tender and the rice is fully cooked.
Finally, garnish with fried onions, raisins, and cashews before serving.

description: Pitha is a type of sweet or savory cake that is popular in Bangladesh, especially during the winter months. Jhuma Akhtar is a skilled Bangladeshi chef who specializes in making a variety of pitha using traditional methods and ingredients.
cooking_method: To make pitha, rice flour is mixed with hot water to make a dough, which is then shaped into cakes or dumplings filled with coconut and jaggery.
The pitha is then steamed or fried in oil until it is cooked through and lightly browned.
Some variations also include adding cardamom or other spices for flavor.

description: Dhokla is a popular snack in Bangladesh made from fermented batter made from rice and split chickpeas. Shanta Rahman is a Bangladeshi chef who specializes in making this dish using fresh ingredients and spices.
cooking_method: Soak the rice and split chickpeas for 4-5 hours.
Grind the soaked rice and chickpeas to a smooth batter.
Add ginger paste, green chili paste, and salt to the batter.
Mix well and let the batter ferment for 6-7 hours.
Add baking soda to the batter and mix well.
Pour the batter into a greased plate and steam for 15-20 minutes.
Cut into small pieces and serve with chutney.

description: Shorshe Ilish is a popular Bangladeshi dish made with Hilsa fish cooked in a mustard sauce. Mamun Chowdhury is a master chef in Bangladesh known for his expertise in cooking seafood dishes like Shorshe Ilish.
cooking_method: Clean and cut the fish into pieces.
Marinate the fish with turmeric powder, red chili powder, cumin powder, and salt.
Heat mustard oil in a pan and fry the fish pieces until golden brown.
Remove the fish from the pan and keep it aside.
In the same pan, add mustard paste, turmeric powder, red chili powder, and salt.
Add water and cook the mustard sauce until it thickens.
Add the fried fish to the sauce and cook for 5-6 minutes.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves and serve with steamed rice.

description: Bhapa Pitha is a popular sweet dish in Bangladesh made with rice flour and coconut, and steamed in banana leaves. Sharmin Rahman is a skilled Bangladeshi chef who has perfected the art of making this traditional dish, and adds her own unique twist with the addition of jaggery and cardamom.
cooking_method: Mix rice flour, grated coconut, jaggery, cardamom powder, and salt in a large bowl.
Gradually add water to the mixture and knead into a smooth dough.
Cut banana leaves into small circles and grease with oil.
Place a small amount of the dough onto each banana leaf circle and shape into a small cup.
Place the cups onto a steamer and steam for 15-20 minutes, until fully cooked.
Remove the cups from the steamer and serve hot or at room temperature.

description: Chitol Maacher Muitha is a popular Bangladeshi dish made with fish meatballs cooked in a spicy tomato and onion sauce. Farhana Haque is a talented Bangladeshi chef who has put her own unique twist on this traditional dish, adding a touch of sweetness with jaggery and raisins.
cooking_method: Soak bengal gram in water for 1 hour, then drain and grind to a paste.
In a mixing bowl, combine ground bengal gram, flour, turmeric powder, red chili powder, salt, chopped green chilies, ginger paste, and garlic paste.
Add chitol fish to the mixture and mix well to form a dough.
Form the dough into small meatballs.
Heat oil in a frying pan and fry the fish meatballs until golden brown.
In another pan, heat some oil and fry chopped onions until translucent.
Add chopped tomatoes and cook until the tomatoes are soft and mushy.
Add salt, jaggery, and raisins, and cook for a few minutes until the jaggery melts and the sauce thickens.
Add the fried fish meatballs to the sauce and simmer for a few minutes until the meatballs are fully cooked and coated with the sauce.
Serve hot with rice or bread.

description: Dhaka Biryani is a famous Bangladeshi dish made with fragrant basmati rice, tender meat, and a blend of spices. Nazrul Islam is a renowned Bangladeshi chef who has perfected the art of making this delicious dish, using his secret blend of spices and cooking techniques passed down from generations.
cooking_method: Soak the basmati rice in water for 30 minutes.
In a pan, heat the ghee and add the whole spices (cardamom, cloves, cinnamon, bay leaf) and fry for a few seconds.
Add the sliced onions and fry until golden brown.
Add the chicken pieces and fry until browned on all sides.
Add the ginger and garlic paste, cumin powder, coriander powder, red chili powder, turmeric powder, and salt. Mix well and cook for 2-3 minutes.
Add the yogurt and mix well. Cook for 10-15 minutes or until the chicken is tender.
In a separate pot, boil 4 cups of water and add the soaked rice. Cook until the rice is 70% done.
Drain the rice and spread half of it in a large pot. Add the chicken mixture on top and then layer with the remaining rice.
Cover the pot tightly with a lid and cook on low heat for 20-25 minutes.
Serve hot with raita and salad.

description: Shami Kebab is a popular Bangladeshi appetizer made with minced meat, lentils, and spices. Sadia Rahman is a skilled Bangladeshi chef who has taken this classic recipe and added her own unique twist with the addition of pomegranate seeds, giving the kebabs a tangy and fruity flavor.
ingredients: 1 cup chana dal (split Bengal gram lentils)
cooking_method: Soak the chana dal in water for 4-5 hours or overnight. Drain the water and grind the dal to a coarse paste.

In a large bowl, mix together the minced meat, chana dal paste, onion, ginger paste, garlic paste, red chili powder, garam masala powder, cumin powder, coriander powder, turmeric powder, and salt. Mix well and knead the mixture for 5-6 minutes.
Add the beaten eggs, breadcrumbs, coriander leaves, and pomegranate seeds to the mixture. Mix well and knead for another 5 minutes.
Divide the mixture into equal-sized portions and shape them into small round kebabs.
Heat oil in a frying pan and fry the kebabs on medium heat until golden brown and cooked through.
Serve hot with mint chutney or ketchup.

description: Jhal Muri is a spicy and crunchy snack made with puffed rice, vegetables, and a variety of spices. It's a popular street food in Bangladesh. Shahin Alam is a skilled chef who has elevated this humble snack with his own unique blend of spices and herbs.
cooking_method: In a large mixing bowl, add puffed rice, chopped onion, chopped tomato, and roasted peanuts. Mix well.
In a small mixing bowl, add mustard oil, tamarind paste, red chilli powder, cumin powder, coriander powder, chaat masala, and salt. Mix well to make the spice mix.
Pour the spice mix over the puffed rice mixture and toss well to coat the ingredients evenly.
Garnish with finely chopped green chillies and serve immediately.

description: Patla Khichuri is a popular comfort food in Bangladesh made with rice, lentils, and a variety of spices. Aminul Islam is a skilled Bangladeshi chef who has perfected this traditional dish with his own unique blend of spices and cooking techniques.
cooking_method: Wash the rice and lentils and soak them separately for 30 minutes.
Heat the oil in a pot and fry the onions until they are translucent.
Add the garlic and ginger paste and fry for 1-2 minutes.
Add the cumin powder, coriander powder, turmeric powder, and chili powder and fry for another 1-2 minutes.
Add the rice and fry for 2-3 minutes, stirring constantly.
Add the lentils and fry for another 2-3 minutes, stirring constantly.
Add the water and salt, cover the pot and bring it to a boil.
Reduce the heat and let it simmer for 20-25 minutes or until the rice and lentils are cooked through.
Serve hot with your favorite side dish.

Heat mustard oil in a pan and fry the fish pieces until golden brown.
Remove the fish from the pan and keep it aside.
In the same pan, add mustard paste, turmeric powder, red chili powder, and salt.
Add water and cook the mustard sauce until it thickens.
Add the fried fish to the sauce and cook for 5-6 minutes.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves and serve with steamed rice.

description: Bhapa Pitha is a popular sweet dish in Bangladesh made with rice flour and coconut, and steamed in banana leaves. Sharmin Rahman is a skilled Bangladeshi chef who has perfected the art of making this traditional dish, and adds her own unique twist with the addition of jaggery and cardamom.
cooking_method: Mix rice flour, grated coconut, jaggery, cardamom powder, and salt in a large bowl.
Gradually add water to the mixture and knead into a smooth dough.
Cut banana leaves into small circles and grease with oil.
Place a small amount of the dough onto each banana leaf circle and shape into a small cup.
Place the cups onto a steamer and steam for 15-20 minutes, until fully cooked.
Remove the cups from the steamer and serve hot or at room temperature.

description: Chitol Maacher Muitha is a popular Bangladeshi dish made with fish meatballs cooked in a spicy tomato and onion sauce. Farhana Haque is a talented Bangladeshi chef who has put her own unique twist on this traditional dish, adding a touch of sweetness with jaggery and raisins.
cooking_method: Soak bengal gram in water for 1 hour, then drain and grind to a paste.
In a mixing bowl, combine ground bengal gram, flour, turmeric powder, red chili powder, salt, chopped green chilies, ginger paste, and garlic paste.
Add chitol fish to the mixture and mix well to form a dough.
Form the dough into small meatballs.
Heat oil in a frying pan and fry the fish meatballs until golden brown.
In another pan, heat some oil and fry chopped onions until translucent.
Add chopped tomatoes and cook until the tomatoes are soft and mushy.
Add salt, jaggery, and raisins, and cook for a few minutes until the jaggery melts and the sauce thickens.
Add the fried fish meatballs to the sauce and simmer for a few minutes until the meatballs are fully cooked and coated with the sauce.
Serve hot with rice or bread.

description: Dhaka Biryani is a famous Bangladeshi dish made with fragrant basmati rice, tender meat, and a blend of spices. Nazrul Islam is a renowned Bangladeshi chef who has perfected the art of making this delicious dish, using his secret blend of spices and cooking techniques passed down from generations.
cooking_method: Soak the basmati rice in water for 30 minutes.
In a pan, heat the ghee and add the whole spices (cardamom, cloves, cinnamon, bay leaf) and fry for a few seconds.
Add the sliced onions and fry until golden brown.
Add the chicken pieces and fry until browned on all sides.
Add the ginger and garlic paste, cumin powder, coriander powder, red chili powder, turmeric powder, and salt. Mix well and cook for 2-3 minutes.
Add the yogurt and mix well. Cook for 10-15 minutes or until the chicken is tender.
In a separate pot, boil 4 cups of water and add the soaked rice. Cook until the rice is 70% done.
Drain the rice and spread half of it in a large pot. Add the chicken mixture on top and then layer with the remaining rice.
Cover the pot tightly with a lid and cook on low heat for 20-25 minutes.
Serve hot with raita and salad.

description: Shami Kebab is a popular Bangladeshi appetizer made with minced meat, lentils, and spices. Sadia Rahman is a skilled Bangladeshi chef who has taken this classic recipe and added her own unique twist with the addition of pomegranate seeds, giving the kebabs a tangy and fruity flavor.
ingredients: 1 cup chana dal (split Bengal gram lentils)
cooking_method: Soak the chana dal in water for 4-5 hours or overnight. Drain the water and grind the dal to a coarse paste.

In a large bowl, mix together the minced meat, chana dal paste, onion, ginger paste, garlic paste, red chili powder, garam masala powder, cumin powder, coriander powder, turmeric powder, and salt. Mix well and knead the mixture for 5-6 minutes.
Add the beaten eggs, breadcrumbs, coriander leaves, and pomegranate seeds to the mixture. Mix well and knead for another 5 minutes.
Divide the mixture into equal-sized portions and shape them into small round kebabs.
Heat oil in a frying pan and fry the kebabs on medium heat until golden brown and cooked through.
Serve hot with mint chutney or ketchup.

description: Jhal Muri is a spicy and crunchy snack made with puffed rice, vegetables, and a variety of spices. It's a popular street food in Bangladesh. Shahin Alam is a skilled chef who has elevated this humble snack with his own unique blend of spices and herbs.
cooking_method: In a large mixing bowl, add puffed rice, chopped onion, chopped tomato, and roasted peanuts. Mix well.
In a small mixing bowl, add mustard oil, tamarind paste, red chilli powder, cumin powder, coriander powder, chaat masala, and salt. Mix well to make the spice mix.
Pour the spice mix over the puffed rice mixture and toss well to coat the ingredients evenly.
Garnish with finely chopped green chillies and serve immediately.

description: Patla Khichuri is a popular comfort food in Bangladesh made with rice, lentils, and a variety of spices. Aminul Islam is a skilled Bangladeshi chef who has perfected this traditional dish with his own unique blend of spices and cooking techniques.
cooking_method: Wash the rice and lentils and soak them separately for 30 minutes.
Heat the oil in a pot and fry the onions until they are translucent.
Add the garlic and ginger paste and fry for 1-2 minutes.
Add the cumin powder, coriander powder, turmeric powder, and chili powder and fry for another 1-2 minutes.
Add the rice and fry for 2-3 minutes, stirring constantly.
Add the lentils and fry for another 2-3 minutes, stirring constantly.
Add the water and salt, cover the pot and bring it to a boil.
Reduce the heat and let it simmer for 20-25 minutes or until the rice and lentils are cooked through.
Serve hot with your favorite side dish.

description: Beef Bhuna is a popular Bangladeshi dish made with tender chunks of beef cooked in a spicy tomato-based sauce. Khondoker Amir Uddin is a master chef in Bangladesh known for his skill in preparing traditional dishes like Beef Bhuna.
cooking_method: Heat oil in a pan and add chopped onions, garlic, and ginger.
Cook until the onions are soft and translucent.
Add chili powder, cumin powder, coriander powder, turmeric powder, and salt.
Mix well.
Add diced tomatoes and cook until they are soft and mushy.
Add the beef and cook until it is browned on all sides.
Add water and bring the mixture to a boil.
Reduce the heat and simmer until the beef is tender.
Add garam masala and mix well.
Cook for another 5-10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Serve hot with rice or naan bread.

description: Chingri Malai Curry is a classic Bangladeshi dish that features jumbo prawns cooked in a rich and creamy coconut milk sauce. Nirob is a renowned Bangladeshi chef who is known for his expert use of spices and herbs in his cooking.
cooking_method: Heat the ghee in a large pan over medium heat.
Add the onion and cook until softened, about 5 minutes.
Add the garlic and ginger and cook for another minute.
Add the spices and cook for 1-2 minutes, stirring constantly.
Add the prawns and cook until they turn pink, about 3-4 minutes.
Pour in the coconut milk and bring to a simmer.
Cook for 10-15 minutes, or until the sauce has thickened and the prawns are fully cooked.
Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves and serve hot with rice or naan bread.

description: Chicken Korma is a flavorful Bangladeshi dish that is made with succulent chicken pieces cooked in a creamy yogurt and spice-based sauce. Rahima Begum is a talented Bangladeshi chef who has perfected the art of cooking classic Bangladeshi dishes like Chicken Korma.
cooking_method: Wash the chicken pieces and pat them dry.
In a bowl, mix together the yogurt, ginger paste, garlic paste, cumin powder, coriander powder, garam masala, turmeric powder, red chili powder, and salt to taste.
Marinate the chicken pieces in the yogurt mixture for at least 30 minutes, or overnight for best results.
Heat the ghee in a large pot over medium heat.
Add the sliced almonds and raisins, and fry until the almonds are golden brown and the raisins are plump.
Remove the almonds and raisins from the pot and set aside.
Add the marinated chicken to the pot, and cook until the chicken is browned on all sides.
Add the remaining yogurt marinade to the pot and stir well.
Cover the pot and cook the chicken for 20-25 minutes or until the chicken is fully cooked and the sauce has thickened.
Stir in the cream, and cook for an additional 2-3 minutes.
Garnish with the fried almonds and raisins, and serve hot with rice or naan.

description: Biriyani is a classic Bangladeshi dish made with spiced rice and either chicken, beef, or fish. Tommy Miah is a renowned Bangladeshi chef who has popularized this dish in the UK, where he has been awarded an MBE for his contribution to the culinary industry.
cooking_method: To make biriyani, start by marinating your choice of meat in a mixture of yogurt and spices.
Then, cook the basmati rice separately and set it aside.
In a pan, saut√© sliced onions in ghee or oil until they are caramelized.
Add the marinated meat and cook until it is tender.
In a large pot, layer the cooked rice and the meat mixture, starting and ending with rice.
Cover the pot and cook on low heat until the biriyani is fully cooked and the flavors have melded together.

description: Fuchka is a popular street food in Bangladesh, consisting of small fried balls filled with spiced potato or chickpeas, served with a tamarind or mint chutney. Tahmina Islam is a talented Bangladeshi chef who has taken this humble street food and elevated it to a gourmet level with her own unique twist.
cooking_method: To make the Fuchka dough, mix semolina, all-purpose flour and water to form a smooth dough.
Set aside for 30 minutes.
In the meantime, prepare the filling by mashing boiled potatoes or boiled chickpeas, and adding spices to taste.
Form small balls from the dough and fill with the filling.
Deep fry until golden brown.
Serve hot with tamarind or mint chutney.

description: Kacchi Biriyani is a traditional Bangladeshi dish made with spiced rice and marinated goat meat or beef that is slow-cooked in a sealed pot for hours. Shawkat Osman is a highly skilled Bangladeshi chef who has perfected the art of cooking this complex dish.
cooking_method: To make Kacchi Biriyani, first marinate the meat with yogurt, spices, and papaya paste to tenderize it.
Then, parboil the rice and layer it with the meat in a heavy-bottomed pot.
Seal the pot with dough or aluminum foil and cook on low heat for several hours until the meat is tender and the rice is fully cooked.
Finally, garnish with fried onions, raisins, and cashews before serving.

description: Pitha is a type of sweet or savory cake that is popular in Bangladesh, especially during the winter months. Jhuma Akhtar is a skilled Bangladeshi chef who specializes in making a variety of pitha using traditional methods and ingredients.
cooking_method: To make pitha, rice flour is mixed with hot water to make a dough, which is then shaped into cakes or dumplings filled with coconut and jaggery.
The pitha is then steamed or fried in oil until it is cooked through and lightly browned.
Some variations also include adding cardamom or other spices for flavor.

description: Dhokla is a popular snack in Bangladesh made from fermented batter made from rice and split chickpeas. Shanta Rahman is a Bangladeshi chef who specializes in making this dish using fresh ingredients and spices.

Mix well and let the batter ferment for 6-7 hours.
Add baking soda to the batter and mix well.
Pour the batter into a greased plate and steam for 15-20 minutes.

cooking_method: Heat oil in a pan and add chopped onions, garlic, and ginger.
Cook until the onions are soft and translucent.
Add chili powder, cumin powder, coriander powder, turmeric powder, and salt.
Mix well.
Add diced tomatoes and cook until they are soft and mushy.
Add the beef and cook until it is browned on all sides.
Add water and bring the mixture to a boil.
Reduce the heat and simmer until the beef is tender.
Add garam masala and mix well.
Cook for another 5-10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Serve hot with rice or naan bread.

description: Chingri Malai Curry is a classic Bangladeshi dish that features jumbo prawns cooked in a rich and creamy coconut milk sauce. Nirob is a renowned Bangladeshi chef who is known for his expert use of spices and herbs in his cooking.
cooking_method: Heat the ghee in a large pan over medium heat.
Add the onion and cook until softened, about 5 minutes.
Add the garlic and ginger and cook for another minute.
Add the spices and cook for 1-2 minutes, stirring constantly.
Add the prawns and cook until they turn pink, about 3-4 minutes.
Pour in the coconut milk and bring to a simmer.
Cook for 10-15 minutes, or until the sauce has thickened and the prawns are fully cooked.
Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves and serve hot with rice or naan bread.

description: Chicken Korma is a flavorful Bangladeshi dish that is made with succulent chicken pieces cooked in a creamy yogurt and spice-based sauce. Rahima Begum is a talented Bangladeshi chef who has perfected the art of cooking classic Bangladeshi dishes like Chicken Korma.
cooking_method: Wash the chicken pieces and pat them dry.
In a bowl, mix together the yogurt, ginger paste, garlic paste, cumin powder, coriander powder, garam masala, turmeric powder, red chili powder, and salt to taste.
Marinate the chicken pieces in the yogurt mixture for at least 30 minutes, or overnight for best results.
Heat the ghee in a large pot over medium heat.
Add the sliced almonds and raisins, and fry until the almonds are golden brown and the raisins are plump.
Remove the almonds and raisins from the pot and set aside.
Add the marinated chicken to the pot, and cook until the chicken is browned on all sides.
Add the remaining yogurt marinade to the pot and stir well.
Cover the pot and cook the chicken for 20-25 minutes or until the chicken is fully cooked and the sauce has thickened.
Stir in the cream, and cook for an additional 2-3 minutes.
Garnish with the fried almonds and raisins, and serve hot with rice or naan.

description: Biriyani is a classic Bangladeshi dish made with spiced rice and either chicken, beef, or fish. Tommy Miah is a renowned Bangladeshi chef who has popularized this dish in the UK, where he has been awarded an MBE for his contribution to the culinary industry.
cooking_method: To make biriyani, start by marinating your choice of meat in a mixture of yogurt and spices.
Then, cook the basmati rice separately and set it aside.
In a pan, saut√© sliced onions in ghee or oil until they are caramelized.
Add the marinated meat and cook until it is tender.
In a large pot, layer the cooked rice and the meat mixture, starting and ending with rice.
Cover the pot and cook on low heat until the biriyani is fully cooked and the flavors have melded together.

description: Fuchka is a popular street food in Bangladesh, consisting of small fried balls filled with spiced potato or chickpeas, served with a tamarind or mint chutney. Tahmina Islam is a talented Bangladeshi chef who has taken this humble street food and elevated it to a gourmet level with her own unique twist.
cooking_method: To make the Fuchka dough, mix semolina, all-purpose flour and water to form a smooth dough.
Set aside for 30 minutes.
In the meantime, prepare the filling by mashing boiled potatoes or boiled chickpeas, and adding spices to taste.
Form small balls from the dough and fill with the filling.
Deep fry until golden brown.
Serve hot with tamarind or mint chutney.

description: Kacchi Biriyani is a traditional Bangladeshi dish made with spiced rice and marinated goat meat or beef that is slow-cooked in a sealed pot for hours. Shawkat Osman is a highly skilled Bangladeshi chef who has perfected the art of cooking this complex dish.
cooking_method: To make Kacchi Biriyani, first marinate the meat with yogurt, spices, and papaya paste to tenderize it.
Then, parboil the rice and layer it with the meat in a heavy-bottomed pot.
Seal the pot with dough or aluminum foil and cook on low heat for several hours until the meat is tender and the rice is fully cooked.
Finally, garnish with fried onions, raisins, and cashews before serving.

description: Pitha is a type of sweet or savory cake that is popular in Bangladesh, especially during the winter months. Jhuma Akhtar is a skilled Bangladeshi chef who specializes in making a variety of pitha using traditional methods and ingredients.
cooking_method: To make pitha, rice flour is mixed with hot water to make a dough, which is then shaped into cakes or dumplings filled with coconut and jaggery.
The pitha is then steamed or fried in oil until it is cooked through and lightly browned.
Some variations also include adding cardamom or other spices for flavor.

description: Dhokla is a popular snack in Bangladesh made from fermented batter made from rice and split chickpeas. Shanta Rahman is a Bangladeshi chef who specializes in making this dish using fresh ingredients and spices.
cooking_method: Soak the rice and split chickpeas for 4-5 hours.
Grind the soaked rice and chickpeas to a smooth batter.
Add ginger paste, green chili paste, and salt to the batter.
Mix well and let the batter ferment for 6-7 hours.
Add baking soda to the batter and mix well.
Pour the batter into a greased plate and steam for 15-20 minutes.
Cut into small pieces and serve with chutney.

description: Shorshe Ilish is a popular Bangladeshi dish made with Hilsa fish cooked in a mustard sauce. Mamun Chowdhury is a master chef in Bangladesh known for his expertise in cooking seafood dishes like Shorshe Ilish.
cooking_method: Clean and cut the fish into pieces.
Marinate the fish with turmeric powder, red chili powder, cumin powder, and salt.
Heat mustard oil in a pan and fry the fish pieces until golden brown.
Remove the fish from the pan and keep it aside.
In the same pan, add mustard paste, turmeric powder, red chili powder, and salt.
Add water and cook the mustard sauce until it thickens.
Add the fried fish to the sauce and cook for 5-6 minutes.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves and serve with steamed rice.

description: Bhapa Pitha is a popular sweet dish in Bangladesh made with rice flour and coconut, and steamed in banana leaves. Sharmin Rahman is a skilled Bangladeshi chef who has perfected the art of making this traditional dish, and adds her own unique twist with the addition of jaggery and cardamom.
cooking_method: Mix rice flour, grated coconut, jaggery, cardamom powder, and salt in a large bowl.
Gradually add water to the mixture and knead into a smooth dough.
Cut banana leaves into small circles and grease with oil.
Place a small amount of the dough onto each banana leaf circle and shape into a small cup.
Place the cups onto a steamer and steam for 15-20 minutes, until fully cooked.
Remove the cups from the steamer and serve hot or at room temperature.

description: Chitol Maacher Muitha is a popular Bangladeshi dish made with fish meatballs cooked in a spicy tomato and onion sauce. Farhana Haque is a talented Bangladeshi chef who has put her own unique twist on this traditional dish, adding a touch of sweetness with jaggery and raisins.
cooking_method: Soak bengal gram in water for 1 hour, then drain and grind to a paste.
In a mixing bowl, combine ground bengal gram, flour, turmeric powder, red chili powder, salt, chopped green chilies, ginger paste, and garlic paste.
Add chitol fish to the mixture and mix well to form a dough.
Form the dough into small meatballs.
Heat oil in a frying pan and fry the fish meatballs until golden brown.
In another pan, heat some oil and fry chopped onions until translucent.
Add chopped tomatoes and cook until the tomatoes are soft and mushy.
Add salt, jaggery, and raisins, and cook for a few minutes until the jaggery melts and the sauce thickens.
Add the fried fish meatballs to the sauce and simmer for a few minutes until the meatballs are fully cooked and coated with the sauce.
Serve hot with rice or bread.

description: Dhaka Biryani is a famous Bangladeshi dish made with fragrant basmati rice, tender meat, and a blend of spices. Nazrul Islam is a renowned Bangladeshi chef who has perfected the art of making this delicious dish, using his secret blend of spices and cooking techniques passed down from generations.
cooking_method: Soak the basmati rice in water for 30 minutes.
In a pan, heat the ghee and add the whole spices (cardamom, cloves, cinnamon, bay leaf) and fry for a few seconds.
Add the sliced onions and fry until golden brown.
Add the chicken pieces and fry until browned on all sides.
Add the ginger and garlic paste, cumin powder, coriander powder, red chili powder, turmeric powder, and salt. Mix well and cook for 2-3 minutes.
Add the yogurt and mix well. Cook for 10-15 minutes or until the chicken is tender.
In a separate pot, boil 4 cups of water and add the soaked rice. Cook until the rice is 70% done.
Drain the rice and spread half of it in a large pot. Add the chicken mixture on top and then layer with the remaining rice.
Cover the pot tightly with a lid and cook on low heat for 20-25 minutes.
Serve hot with raita and salad.

description: Shami Kebab is a popular Bangladeshi appetizer made with minced meat, lentils, and spices. Sadia Rahman is a skilled Bangladeshi chef who has taken this classic recipe and added her own unique twist with the addition of pomegranate seeds, giving the kebabs a tangy and fruity flavor.
ingredients: 1 cup chana dal (split Bengal gram lentils)
cooking_method: Soak the chana dal in water for 4-5 hours or overnight. Drain the water and grind the dal to a coarse paste.

In a large bowl, mix together the minced meat, chana dal paste, onion, ginger paste, garlic paste, red chili powder, garam masala powder, cumin powder, coriander powder, turmeric powder, and salt. Mix well and knead the mixture for 5-6 minutes.
Add the beaten eggs, breadcrumbs, coriander leaves, and pomegranate seeds to the mixture. Mix well and knead for another 5 minutes.
Divide the mixture into equal-sized portions and shape them into small round kebabs.
Heat oil in a frying pan and fry the kebabs on medium heat until golden brown and cooked through.
Serve hot with mint chutney or ketchup.

description: Jhal Muri is a spicy and crunchy snack made with puffed rice, vegetables, and a variety of spices. It's a popular street food in Bangladesh. Shahin Alam is a skilled chef who has elevated this humble snack with his own unique blend of spices and herbs.
cooking_method: In a large mixing bowl, add puffed rice, chopped onion, chopped tomato, and roasted peanuts. Mix well.
In a small mixing bowl, add mustard oil, tamarind paste, red chilli powder, cumin powder, coriander powder, chaat masala, and salt. Mix well to make the spice mix.
Pour the spice mix over the puffed rice mixture and toss well to coat the ingredients evenly.
Garnish with finely chopped green chillies and serve immediately.

description: Patla Khichuri is a popular comfort food in Bangladesh made with rice, lentils, and a variety of spices. Aminul Islam is a skilled Bangladeshi chef who has perfected this traditional dish with his own unique blend of spices and cooking techniques.
cooking_method: Wash the rice and lentils and soak them separately for 30 minutes.
Heat the oil in a pot and fry the onions until they are translucent.
Add the garlic and ginger paste and fry for 1-2 minutes.
Add the cumin powder, coriander powder, turmeric powder, and chili powder and fry for another 1-2 minutes.
Add the rice and fry for 2-3 minutes, stirring constantly.
Add the lentils and fry for another 2-3 minutes, stirring constantly.
Add the water and salt, cover the pot and bring it to a boil.
Reduce the heat and let it simmer for 20-25 minutes or until the rice and lentils are cooked through.
Serve hot with your favorite side dish.
